cycle_summaries.summary: First v2 construct-first landscape mapping cycle. Scanned 25 structural signals across 7 source categories. Graded all 25 above threshold (4/10). Clustered into 14 opportunity themes. Constructed 20 distinct business models across 13 verified opportunities. 4 Tier 1, 4 Tier 2, 5 Tier 3.

key_patterns_identified.name: Multi-Sector Baumol Cure Convergence
key_patterns_identified.description: Healthcare, legal, accounting, insurance ALL showing simultaneous Baumol cure signals. The stored energy in above-CPI sectors is releasing simultaneously due to AI cost collapse.
key_patterns_identified.implications: The Baumol cure is the dominant structural force in the AI economy. Any sector with decades of above-CPI inflation and >60% cognitive work is an opportunity.

key_patterns_identified.name: Demographic Gap + AI Readiness Convergence
key_patterns_identified.description: Nursing, insurance, accounting, and skilled trades all show aging workforce + AI maturation simultaneously. Creates regulatory tailwind (necessity-driven acceptance).
key_patterns_identified.implications: Demographic gaps are the entry wedge. Where humans are scarce, AI resistance lowest.

key_patterns_identified.name: Regulatory Fragmentation as Structural Moat
key_patterns_identified.description: 47 states + EU AI Act + sector-specific regulation creating compliance maze. First navigators build durable moats.
key_patterns_identified.implications: Regulatory barriers are the strongest moat source in the 2026 AI economy. Build compliance first.

key_patterns_identified.name: PE Distress + AI Cost Collapse Double Disruption
key_patterns_identified.description: Refinancing wall + AI margin compression hitting simultaneously. Assets available at distressed prices can be served at 10x lower cost.
key_patterns_identified.implications: 12-24 month window for distressed asset acquisition. Time-sensitive.

key_patterns_identified.name: Jevons Expansion Consistently 3-5x in Professional Services
key_patterns_identified.description: Accounting (70% unserved), legal (SMBs priced out), financial advisory (80% without CFO), education (80% without tutors). Unserved market is 3-5x current served market.
key_patterns_identified.implications: TAM calculations based on current market size understate the opportunity by 3-5x. The REAL market is the unserved population.

transmission_chains_status.note: PE bankruptcies confirming firm behavior change
Macro trend confirmed but micro opportunities still forming
Shakeout visible but turning point timing uncertain

under_explored_areas: Agriculture/AgTech AI (Davis, CA location could be an advantage)
Government/municipal services AI (large Baumol sector, unclear regulatory path)
Real estate transaction AI (large market but competitive density unknown)
Mental health / therapy AI (regulatory moat forming, Utah first law)
Manufacturing quality control / supply chain AI (nearshoring-adjacent)
Veterinary services AI (v1 identified sparse competition, worth re-examining in v2 framework)
Non-English-language professional services AI (LATAM beyond cross-border)

top_combined_scoring.note: Highest combined score: strong opportunity + strong fit
Largest economic force but needs domain hire
Strong validation (Avallon, Allianz) + LATAM expansion path
Best founder fit (24/25) but opportunity score lower
Large force, YC-endorsed, needs bar licensing

founder_fit_analysis.recommendation: SMB Accounting/Finance is the highest combined score AND the most capital-efficient to test. But the LATAM corridor (24/25 fit) and Insurance Claims AI (strong validation + LATAM path) are also exceptional founder-opportunity matches. The optimal strategy may COMBINE multiple opportunities: start with SMB accounting (fastest to revenue), add LATAM expansion (founder advantage), and layer insurance claims processing as a second vertical.

cycle_summaries.v1_integration_note: v1 Customer Support thesis (score 72) remains valid as a Tier 2 opportunity in v2 framework. It is a ~$20B economic force with strong structural advantage (BPO inversion barrier). v2 surfaces larger opportunities (Healthcare $200B+, Accounting $120B+, Legal $80B+) that v1 filtered out due to barriers v2 recognizes as moats. v1's Veterinary thesis (score 62) maps to Tier 3 in v2 -- sparse competition confirmed but small TAM. RECOMMENDATION: v1 insights are valuable context. Do NOT discard them. Layer them into v2 landscape as validated data points.
next_cycle_direction: Deep-dive competitor analysis on top 3 Tier 1 opportunities (accounting, healthcare, insurance)
Scan under-explored areas: AgTech, government, mental health, manufacturing
Build unit economics models with live inference pricing for top 3
Map regulatory pathways (CPA licensing, HIPAA, state insurance) with specific costs and timelines
Customer discovery: interview 10+ potential customers for top 2 opportunities
Test v1 Customer Support thesis within v2 scoring to produce comparable ranking
Scan LATAM market specifically: which professional services have weakest incumbents?

notes: v2 engine. Previous 11 cycles ran v1 (prosecutorial filtering). v2 uses construct-first landscape mapping. Cycle numbering restarts at 1.
